From Wiktionary, the free dictionary

English

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From interview +‎ -er.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • (General American) IPA(key): /ˈɪntɚvjuɚ/
  • (Received Pronunciation) IPA(key): /ˈɪntəvjuːə/
  • Audio (Southern England):(file)

Noun

[edit]

interviewer (plural interviewers)

  1. One who interviews.
    • 2001, Foster Hirsh, quoting Woody Allen, Love, Sex, Death, and the Meaning of Life: The Films of Woody Allen‎[1]:
      “I don't consider myself a nebbish,” Woody told interviewers early in his career, “but everyone else does.”
    • 2021 November 3, Dr Joseph Brennan, “Boxes with functions across the centuries”, in RAIL, number 943, page 54:
      "I am glad to know you preserve that old signal box at the top of the incline. Is it not the oldest in Scotland?" an interviewer asks John Conacher, General Manager of the North British Railway, in 1898.

Derived terms

[edit]
  • intervieweress

Related terms

[edit]
  • interviewee (a person who is interviewed)

Descendants

[edit]
  • → Dutch: interviewer
  • → French: interviewer
  • → German: Interviewer
  • → Japanese: インタビュアー (intabyuā)
  • → Russian: интервью́ер (intɛrvʹjújer)

Translations

[edit]
one who interviews
  • Albanian: intervistues m, intervistuese f
  • Asturian: entrevistador m
  • Catalan: entrevistador m
  • Chinese:
    Mandarin: 訪問者 / 访问者 (zh) (fǎngwènzhě)
  • Dutch: interviewer (nl) m, interviewster (nl) f
  • Esperanto: intervjuisto
  • Finnish: haastattelija (fi)
  • French: intervieweur (fr) m, intervieweuse (fr) f
  • Galician: entrevistador m, entrevistadora f
  • German: Befrager (de) m, Befragerin (de) f, Interviewer (de) m, Interviewerin (de) f
  • Icelandic: spyrill (is) m, spyrjandi m
  • Ido: interviuvanto (io)
  • Italian: intervistatore (it) m, intervistatrice (it) f
  • Japanese: インタビュアー (ja) (intabyuā), 会見者 (かいけんしゃ, kakkensha)
  • Korean: 면접관(面接官) (myeonjeopgwan)
  • Kyrgyz: маекчи (mayekci)
  • Macedonian: интервју́ер m (intervjúer), интервју́ерка f (intervjúerka)
  • Malay: penemu duga
  • Manx: co-akiner m
  • Maori: kaipatapatai, kaiuiui
  • Polish: przeprowadzający wywiad m, przeprowadzająca wywiad f
  • Portuguese: entrevistador (pt) m, entrevistadora (pt) f
  • Russian: интервью́ер (ru) m (intɛrvʹjújer), опра́шивающий (ru) m (oprášivajuščij)
  • Spanish: entrevistador (es) m, entrevistadora f
  • Turkish: röportajcı (tr)
  • Ukrainian: інтерв'юе́р m (intervʺjuér), інтерв'юе́рка f (intervʺjuérka), інтерв'ює́р m (intervʺjujér), інтерв'ює́рка f (intervʺjujérka)
  • Volapük: (♂♀) bespikan, (♂) hibespikan, (♀) jibespikan
  • Welsh: cyfwelydd (cy) m

Anagrams

[edit]
  • reinterview

Dutch

[edit]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ˈɪntərˌvjuːər/
  • Audio:(file)

Noun

[edit]

interviewer m (plural interviewers, diminutive interviewertje n)

  1. a male interviewer

Related terms

[edit]
  • interviewen
  • herinterviewen
  • interview
  • interviewster
  • geïnterviewde

French

[edit]

Etymology 1

[edit]

Borrowed from English to interview.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ɛ̃.tɛʁ.vju.ve/, /in.tɛʁ.vju.ve/, (anglicized) /ɛ̃.tɛʁ.vju.we/
  • Audio:(file)

Verb

[edit]

interviewer

  1. to interview

compound — simple imperative of avoir + past participle — simple imperative of avoir + past participle simple imperative of avoir + past participle —
1 The French gerund is usable only with the preposition en.
2 In less formal writing or speech, these tenses may be found to have been replaced in the following way:
past historic → present perfect
past anterior → pluperfect
imperfect subjunctive → present subjunctive
pluperfect subjunctive → past subjunctive

(Christopher Kendris [1995], Master the Basics: French, pp. 77, 78, 79, 81).

Etymology 2

[edit]

Borrowed from English interviewer.

Alternative forms

[edit]
  • intervieweur (post-1990 spelling)

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ɛ̃.tɛʁ.vju.vœʁ/, /in.tɛʁ.vju.vœʁ/, (anglicized) /ɛ̃.tɛʁ.vju.wœʁ/

Noun

[edit]

interviewer m (plural interviewers, feminine intervieweuse)

  1. interviewer

Further reading

[edit]
  • “interviewer”, in Trésor de la langue française informatisé [Digitized Treasury of the French Language], 2012.
